html:
Apr 13 (IFR)

  • Nexity raises €240m through new CB after revising terms
  • Air France-KLM completes first step of capital increase 
  • Affluent Medical to reattempt Paris IPO
  • Acciona shareholders approve energy unit IPO

JP Morgan is in the market this evening offering 50m shares in Airtel Africa on behalf of an undisclosed seller, and representing 1.3% of its share capital. At tonight’s close of 84.8p and without a discount, the deal size could reach £42.4m. The seller will be locked up for 90 days.

Regular issuer Nexity was slightly caught out on Tuesday on its return to equity-linked as investors failed to bite on a new issue within launch terms due to the strong rally in the French property developer's shares over recent weeks and months.

The liability management exercise saw the company buying back convertibles and financing that with a new seven-year issue, reprising the same trade it did in 2016. The buyback passed its minimum threshold of securing 60% of the outstanding €270m of 0.125% 2023s in the morning and later in the afternoon the premium range was revised down to drive demand for the new issue.

There was no pre-sounding ahead of the offer of 2028 bonds with the OCEANE structure (convertible into new or existing shares) with a coupon of 0.375%–0.875% and a premium of 40%–45%. The base size was set at €240m, with a €30m upsize option.

The repurchase price of €66.60–€66.90, including accrued interest, was a 0.5%–1% premium to a market level of €66.20, according to a banker on the deal. Those bonds are still out of the money with a conversion price of €50.8703, according to Refinitiv data, versus Tuesday's close of €44.28.

The key reference for the new issue was the seven-year CB issued by Nexity in 2018, with those using an ORNANE structure (net-share settled) and paying a 0.25% coupon. Those 2025s are still pretty balanced with a conversion price of €57.0447 and were used to calculate a credit spread of 270bp on the new bonds, with implied volatility at launch of just below 24% to just over 30%.

The new bonds offered a higher coupon in addition to seeking a higher premium compared to the existing bonds. As neither of the outstanding bonds is in the money or broken the relative value was important. Investors felt that a share price that has nearly doubled since late October and is up 20% since late February has little further to go so the 40% premium was too high, said a second banker. Shares closed at €44.60 on February 26 2020 ahead of the Covid sell-off.

The premium was revised to 35%–40%, with pricing to follow at 35% with a 0.875% coupon. Final terms were still to be published at 7:30pm in London but bankers on the deal said the change had the desired effect, leading to a high-quality book. Long-only investors were dominant, as expected with a French issuer, and many investors were switching into the new CB. The company opted not to push and kept the deal at €240m.

The bonds can be called from four years with a 130% hurdle and there is a clean-up call at 85%. Dividend protection is included.

BNP Paribas, Credit Agricole and JP Morgan were joint bookrunners.

Subscription for Air France-KLM's capital increase opened on Tuesday with shareholders offered 186.1m shares at €4.84 to raise €900.7m, rising to €1.036bn with an extension option.

Subscription runs until Thursday, but banks have already lined up buyers if shareholders do not want all the offered stock.

On Monday evening an ABB of €255m was completed, but allocations will only be confirmed once orders from shareholders have been filled.

Shares were offered in the ABB at a range of €4.84 to the market close of €5.314 and priced at the bottom, representing a discount of 8.9% and setting the price for the whole fundraising.

The airline operator said that the strength of demand in the ABB means it will exercise at least half of the upsize option so proceeds will be at least €968.2m. Full exercise of the upsize option will see its share capital increase by 50%.

The French state, the company's largest shareholder with a stake of about 14.29%, is investing €590m in the capital increase, and China Eastern Airlines €110m. The Dutch state and Delta Airlines, which own 14% and 8.8%, respectively, are not participating.

A wall-crossing prior to launch meant Tuesday's ABB was already covered at launch.

Credit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, HSBC and Natixis are joint global coordinators, and joint bookrunners with Santander and SocieteGenerale.

Air France-KLM shares ended down 5% on Tuesday at €5.0460 each.

French medtech company Affluent Medical has launched pre-marketing for an IPO in Paris nearly three years after it tried to float on the growth market.

Berenberg is the global coordinator, and joint bookrunner with Midcap Partners and BNPParibas unit Portzamparcon the US$50m-plus deal.

Affluent previously attempted an IPO in June 2018 when the deal size was around €40m and the market cap approximately €120m.

The company develops medical prostheses to treat incontinence and heart disease and the IPO proceeds will fund studies for new and improved products and build a salesforce along with repaying some debt.

Truffle Capital is the majority owner with about 70% of the company.

Timing and the structure of the float remains open-ended at this stage.

Affluent raised €15.8m in a private placement in June. It reached a key milestone last year, with all of its products reaching the clinical phase of development.

Shareholders in Acciona have given the green light for the Spanish renewables and infrastructure group to spin-off and list its energy division.

An EGM was held on Monday and the spin-off was the sole item on the agenda. Shareholders backed the move with 99.8% of votes cast.

In February the company said it had started the process to separate and list at least 25% of its energy unit. Acciona has a market cap of about €7.7bn and energy is one of two main units.

The largest operation by revenue is infrastructure at 69% of 2020 revenue, 28% came from energy and there was a small contribution from other activities. However the energy unit accounted for 74% of the group's €1.1bn Ebitda in 2020.

Shares in Acciona closed down 0.3% on Tuesday at €140.70 each.

Spanish renewables company Ecoener launched pre-marketing for its IPO last week and Repsol is also planning to spin off and list its renewables business this year.

Renewables developer and retailer Capital Energy recently decided against a potential market listing but has not ruled out listing in the future, a spokesperson said.

This week’s deals

Monday

Air France-KLM: €190m primary ABB, subject to clawback, increase option of €130m, shares on offer at €4.84 to market close of €5.314 (max discount of 8.9%). Credit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, Natixis, Banco Santander, Societe Generale.

Springwater Special Situations (US – SPAC): US$150m Nasdaq IPO, 15m (one share, one-half warrant exercisable at US$11.50) at US$10 per unit, books close April 12. ABN AMRO, EarlyBirdCapital

Tuesday

Nexity (France – Real estate): €240m seven-year convertible bonds (OCEANE), €30m upsize not used, coupon 0.875% (0.375%–0.875%), premium 35% (35%–40%, from 40%–45%). BNP Paribas, Credit Agricole, JP Morgan

Thursday

Cellnex (Spain – Telecoms infrastructure): €7bn rights issue, 192.6m on 19-for-48 basis at €36.33 (17% discount to €43.75 TERP), subscription March 1–15, result/rump April 21. Barclays, BNP Paribas, Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan

Tristar Transport (Dubai – Energy logistics): Dh528m–Dh647m (US$144m–US$176m) Dubai Financial Market, 199m (US$120m–$146m) primary, c. 41m secondary, no greenshoe, free-float min. 20%, books April 4–15, pricing April 16, trading April 22. Bank of America, Citigroup, First Abu Dhabi, HSBC, Societe Generale

Pipeline

PENDING – Great Point Entertainment (UK – Fund)

Up to £200m London specialist fund segment IPO, 200m shares at 100p, prospectus February 11, books close March 3, result March 4, trading March 9. N+1 Singer

April 21 – SSP (UK – Food Concessions)

£475m fully underwritten rights issue, 258m (48%) shares at 184p on a 12-for-25 basis, 37.3% discount to TERP of 293.3p, subscription April 7–21, result April 22. Barclays, Goldman Sachs, HSBC, JP Morgan, BNP Paribas, Bank of America, Mediobanca

April 22 – Gore Street Energy Storage Fund (UK)

Up to £197m follow-on, up to 190m shares at 102p (6.2% discount to April 1 close of 108.7p, 2.4% premium to last reported NAV of 99.6p), books April 6–22, result April 23. JP Morgan, Shore Capital

April 22 – Hemnet (Sweden – Property listings)

US$250m–$300m Nasdaq Stockholm all-secondary IPO, books c. April 15–22. Carnegie, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, Barclays, Nordea

April 29 – Impact Healthcare REIT (UK – Care homes)

£50m follow-on, fixed price of 111.5p (2.5% discount to April 1 close of 114.4p, 1.8% premium to last reported NAV of 109.58p), books April 4–29, result April 30. RBC, Winterflood.

April – Allfunds (Netherlands – Wealth management platform)

c. €2bn Euronext Amsterdam IPO, all-secondary, min. 25% free-float, pre-marketing from April 7. BNPParibas, Citigroup, Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, Barclays, Bank of America, CaixaBank, HSBC, IMI-IntesaSanpaolo, ING,Santander.

April – Darktrace (UK – Cyber security)

LSE IPO, primary float with secondary greenshoe, pre-marketing from April 12. Berenberg, Jefferies, KKR, Needham & Company, Piper Sandler & Co.

April – Segezha (Russia – Paper production)

Rbs30bn (US$389m) primary and secondary Moscow float, pre-marketing from April 12. JP Morgan, UBS, VTB Capital, Alfa Capital Markets, Bank of America,Renaissance Capital. 

April – SECO (Italy – Technology)

€115m Milan float, 27m primary shares, 10.77m secondary shares, 15% greenshoe, 40%–45% free-float, pre-marketing from April 12. Goldman Sachs, Mediobanca

April – Synlab (Germany – Medical testing)

€400m-plus Frankfurt IPO, €400m primary, undisclosed secondary tranche, pre-marketing from April 7. Goldman Sachs, JP Morgan, Bank of America, Barclays, Deutsche Bank, HSBC, Jefferies, UniCredit.

April – Trustly (Sweden – Payments)

SKr8bn-plus (US$934m) Stockholm IPO, c. €6bn–€9bn valuation estimates, pre-marketing from April 12. Carnegie, Goldman Sachs, JP MorganCitigroup, Bank of America, BNPParibas, Deutsche Bank, SEB, Swedbank/Kepler Cheuvreux, Rabobank.

April – Grupo Ecoener (Spain – Renewables)

Up to €200m all-primary Spanish IPO, 10% primary greenshoe, pre-marketing from April 7. SocieteGenerale, BancoSabadell, Credit Agricole, CaixaBank, HSBC

April – PensionBee (UK – Online Platform)

£60m LSE high growth segment IPO, £55m primary, £5m secondary, pre-marketing from March 30, admission in April. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods

April – Polypeptide (Switzerland – Drug producer)

c. €600m SIX Swiss listing, SFr200m in primary with undisclosed secondary tranche, valuation c. €1.5bn, pre-marketing from April 12. Bank of America, Credit Suisse, Morgan Stanley, Berneberg, Danske Bank, ZKB 

April – OPDenergy (Spain – Renewables)

€417m IPO, €400m primary, €17m secondary, pre-marketing from April 8. Citigroup, Santander, Alantra, Bank of America, Berenberg, Royal Bank of Canada. Evercore, Rothschild advising

April – EuroHold (Bulgaria – Holding company)

Lv197.5m (US$121m) rights issue, 79m at Lv2.50, April 10 EGM.

April – Piraeus Financial Holding (Greece – Bank)

€1bn capital increase, EGM April 7. Goldman Sachs, UBS advising

April – Pegasus Europe (SPAC)

Amsterdam IPO of several hundred million euros, sponsors Tikehau Capital, Financiere Agache, Jean Pierre Mustier, Diego De Giorgi. Citigroup, JP Morgan

June – Vallourec (France – Steel tubes)

€300m capital increase backstopped by lenders and bondholders, approval at EGM in April.

TBD – NextEnergy Renewables (UK – Fund)

c. £300m London IPO, 300m shares at 100p, books February 15–March 4, on hold March 4. JP Morgan, Kempen

H1 – JP Morgan Global Core Real Assets (UK)

£80m-plus placing, offer for subscription and intermediaries offer at 100p, timetable due before summer 2021. JP Morgan

H2 – Oxford Nanopore (UK – DNA sequencing)

LSE IPO, IP Group 15% stake valued at £340.3m.

2021 – Keliber (Finland – Lithium mining)

Helsinki IPO. Carnegie, Nordea

2021 – Giochi Preziosi (Italy – Toys)

IPO. Banca Akros, Banca IMI, Barclays, Jefferies, Santander (Rothschild advising)
